title: LeT Commander Abu Saifullah Nizamani Shot Dead by Unidentified Gunmen in Pakistan | Times Now
content: LeT Commander Abu Saifullah Nizamani Shot Dead by Unidentified Gunmen in Pakistan | Times Now Open Popup Times Now Times Now Navbharat Zoom ET Now ET Now Swadesh Times Drive Health and Me Digit Marathi Telugu Tamil Bengali Kannada Malayalam Unilist Theme Live tv World US UK Europe Asia Middle East Australia Canada Trending: Mexican Navy Ship Noida Water Crisis Trump’s Advisory Board Bengaluru Weather ISRO EOS-09 Satellite Paresh Rawal Hyderabad Charminar Fire Himachal 12th Result Live HBSE 10th Result 2025 India squad Announcement news world news asia LeT Commander Abu Saifullah Nizamani Shot Dead by Unidentified Gunmen in Pakistan Razullah Nizamani, also known by his alias Abu Saifullah or Ghazi Abu Saifullah, a key commander of the proscribed terror outfit Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT), was shot dead by unidentified gunmen in Pakistan’s Sindh province. Reported by : Bhavatosh Singh Updated May 19, 2025, 00:09 IST Saiffulah was part of LeT module that carried out several attacks Kashmir Valley. Razullah Nizamani, also known by his alias Abu Saifullah or Ghazi Abu Saifullah, a key commander of the proscribed terror outfit Lashkar-e-Taiba ( LeT ), was shot dead by unidentified gunmen in Pakistan ’s Sindh province . He was shot dead near Matli Phalkara Chowk, sources confirmed on Sunday. Saiffulah was part of LeT module that carried out several attacks Kashmir Valley. Also Read: Operation Keller: Top LeT Commander, 2 Others Killed in Shopian, ‘War Like Stores’ Recovered, Says Indian Army Saifullah/Vinod Kumar/Md. Salim was allegedly involved with Lashkar-e-Taiba's Nepal module, handling recruitment, finance, logistics, and facilitating operative movements across the Indo-Nepal border. He purportedly worked with LeT's Azam Cheema and Yaqoob, the group's chief accountant. Saifullah allegedly operated under the alias Vinod Kumar, married a Nepali citizen, Nagma Banu, and orchestrated several attacks, including the 2006 RSS Headquarters attack in Nagpur, the 2001 CRPF attack in Rampur, and the 2005 ISC attack in Bangalore, the sources said. He was reportedly based in Matli, Badin, in Pakistan's Sindh province, focusing on recruitment and fundraising for LeT/Jamat-ud-Dawah, sources added. Terms of Use SITEMAP Contact Us Mint Apps View Less - View More + Copyright © HT Digital Streams Limited All Rights Reserved. ‘Mother held her kids tight’: Eyewitness recalls haunting scene as 17 from one family perish in Hyderabad fire A total of 17 people, including children, lost their lives in the fire incident that broke out at a building at Hyderabad's Gulzar House near Charminar on Sunday morning. Written By Swastika Das Sharma Updated 18 May 2025, 03:14 PM IST Firefighters present at the spot after a fire broke out at the Gulzar House near Charminar, in Hyderabad ( ANI ) When a short circuit caused an entire building to go up in flames near Hyderabad's Gulzar House, locals and fire tenders found it difficult to enter, given the nature of the construction of the house. By the time they were inside, all they could find was heartbreaking scenes in an incident where 17 were left dead. Local residents were the first responders to the accident, rushing to the house where the fire broke out. As per a report by NDTV, Zahir, who is a bangle seller, was among them. The local told the news channel that when he entered the house, he saw a heartbreaking scene – a woman embracing her children in a desperate attempt to save them from the flames. They were charred in that fashion. “We managed to get inside shortly after the fire started. The flames were huge. Inside the room, a woman had hugged children. She was dead,” Zahir was quoted as saying by NDTV. Another eyewitness, Zahid, who was also among the first responders, told news agency ANI that the main gate of the building was engulfed in massive flames, which prevented them from entering. Also Read | Hyderabad: 17, including 8 kids, killed in fire at Gulzar House near Charminar Also Read | Massive fire breaks out in a three-storey building in Hyderabad's Begum Bazaar “We could not enter the building through the main gate as it was engulfed in flames, so we broke the shutter to go inside. Then 5-6 of us broke through a wall and entered the first floor. But the whole place was completely engulfed in flames,” he said. 17 dead in Hyderabad fire A total of 17 people, including children, lost their lives in the fire incident that broke out at a building at Hyderabad's Gulzar House near Charminar on Sunday morning. “There was a fire incident in Krishna Pearls shop and the residential complex in Gulzar House area. The Fire department received the call at 6:16 am and dispatched 11 fire engines with sufficient staff by 6:17 am... The fire department used breathing operators and oxygen masks to rescue the people... The information is that 17 people could not survive... The preliminary examination shows that the cause was a short circuit,” Telangana Disaster Response and Fire Services DG Y Nagi Reddy said. Also Read | Watch: Fire breaks out at Richland complex in Bhiwandi, firefighters on scene A list of the names of the deceased was released, confirming that all of them were from the same family. In a post on X, Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed anguish over the loss of lives due to the fire tragedy in Hyderabad. He announced ₹ 2 lakh for the kin of those who died and ₹ 50,000 to the injured. “Deeply anguished by the loss of lives due to a fire tragedy in Hyderabad, Telangana. Condolences to those who have lost their loved ones. May the injured recover soon. An ex-gratia of ₹ 2 lakh from PMNRF would be given to the next of kin of each deceased. The injured would be given ₹ 50,000: PM,” the post said. Stay updated with the latest Trending , India , World and United States news. Get breaking news and key updates here on Mint!
